question: Question_04_(a)
statement:
Consider the Fourier series

\begin{align*}t^2 - t = \sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty c_ne^{2\pi int}\end{align*}

for $0 \leq t \leq 1$.

\textbf{(a)} What is the definition of the inner product
$\langle f,g \rangle$ for two complex valued function \emph{$f$(t)} and
\emph{g(t)} defined on $0 \leq t \leq 1$?
sols:
The inner product is defined as

\begin{align*}\left \langle f,g \right \rangle=\int_{0}^{1}f(t)\overline{g(t)}dt\end{align*}

This is the continuous equivalent of the inner product for vectors,
where we have the sum of the multiplied components of the vectors.
hints:
The inner product of two functions returns a single number, and
considers the entire domain of both complex functions.
